normalised: Cardiology, eh? It's a field that's close to my heart, literally! My grandfather, bless his soul, had a couple of scares. You know, those chest-clutching, "call Doctor Sharma!" moments. So, I've kind of become a self-proclaimed expert, or at least, a very concerned family member. I figured I'd share some of what I've picked up on my journey into understanding more about heart health.

unnormalised: First off, letâ€™s talk about the lingo. You'll hear terms like "ECG" (that's electrocardiogram, by the way) and "Angiogram". An ECG is like a snapshot of your heart's electrical activity, while an Angiogram is more like a detailed map of your blood vessels using dye and X-rays. My grandpa had both done, at Nanavati Hospital in Mumbai. The bill was around Rs. 35000 for the Angiogram, if I recall correctly.
normalised: First off, let's talk about the lingo. You'll hear terms like "E-C-G" (that's electrocardiogram, by the way) and "Angiogram". An E-C-G is like a snapshot of your heart's electrical activity, while an Angiogram is more like a detailed map of your blood vessels using dye and X-rays. My grandpa had both done, at Nanavati Hospital in Mumbai. The bill was around rupee thirty five thousand for the Angiogram, if I recall correctly.

unnormalised: Then there are the baddies â€“ cholesterol, blood pressure, and stress. Cholesterol, especially LDL cholesterol, is like the "bad guy" of heart health. It can build up in your arteries, causing them to narrow (that's atherosclerosis for you). High blood pressure (anything consistently above 140/90 mmHg, as I understand it) puts extra strain on your heart. And stress? Well, we all know how stress can affect us, especially living in a city like Bangalore!

Well, we all know how stress can affect us, especially living in a city like Bangalore!

unnormalised: The good news is that you can fight back! Exercise is key. Dr. Reddy always told my grandfather to walk for at least 30 mins every day. Diet also plays a huge role. Think more veggies, fruits, and whole grains. Less oily bajjis and more dal-roti, you know? And seriously, find ways to de-stress. Maybe some yoga, meditation, or just spending time with family and friends. My Dadi swears by her evening walks after 7 PM and chai with her friends, and they gossip about who knows what!

unnormalised: Now, I'm no Dr., of course. I am just sharing my anecdotal experiences, I urge you to consult with a medical professional if you are experiencing any sort of discomfort. The point is to be proactive. Don't wait for a crisis like my grandfather did. Regular check-ups are crucial. See your cardiologist, get your cholesterol and blood pressure checked, and discuss any concerns you have. It's especially important if you have a family history of heart disease, like we do.
